snippet: Rahm Emanuel, Chicago’s incumbent mayor, is viewed as the front-runner for re-election next week, but a worry for his campaign is how he will do with black voters.
abstract: Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel is seen as front-runner in his bid for second term, but faces uncertainty over support among black voters, who comprise one-third of city's population of 2.7 million; must gain at least one vote over 50 percent to avoid runoff against any of four lesser-financed, less-well-known candidates.
lead_paragraph: Rahm Emanuel, Chicago’s incumbent mayor, is viewed as the front-runner for re-election next week, but a worry for his campaign is how he will do with black voters.

headline.seo: Rahm Emanuel’s Campaign Worries How He Will Fare With Black Voters
headline.main: Re-election Bid Offers Test of Mayor’s Appeal to ‘Two Chicagos’
headline.print_headline: Re-election Bid Offers Test of Mayor’s Appeal to ‘Two Chicagos’
